questions.text: What is the recommended area per worker in a factory, considering that any height above a specified limit is not taken into account?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B- 500 cubic feet

Factory Act

Definition

An establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used or 20 or more workers where power is not used.

Applicability

Applies to all of India and covers all factories, including perennial and seasonal factories.

Age Restrictions

 
  • Prohibits employment of children below 14 years of age.
  • 15-18 year olds need fitness certificate for factory work from a certified surgeon

Hours of Work
  • Work limited to 48 hours/week or 9 hours/day; max 60 hours/week with overtime.
  • Adolescents: max 4.5 hours/day.
  • Women and adolescents: work hours 6 am to 7 pm.

Leave
  • Grants 1 day of leave per 15 days of work for adolescents
  • 1 day per 30 days of work for adults.
  • Permits accumulation of leaves up to 40 days for adolescents and 30 days for adults.

Health & Safety
  • Mandates a minimum of 500 cubic feet of space per worker.
  • Requires 1 safety officer per 1000 workers.

Welfare

Stipulates 1 welfare officer per 500 workers, 1 canteen per 250 workers, and 1 crèche per 30 women workers.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy is brought to the OPD. He fell on his outstretched arm while riding on his cycle. Clinical examination findings are presented in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Dorsal displacement supracondylar fracture of humerus

options.label: C
options.text: Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus

questions.correct_answer: C. Malunion of a supracondylar fracture of humerus
questions.explanation:
Supracondylar Fractures

Mechanism of injury

Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)

Location

Humerus fractures just above the condyles.

Displacements

The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by

  • Posterior shift (Due to Impaction)
  • Posterior Tilt
  • Proximal shift
  • Medial shift/ Tilt
  • Internal rotation

Types
  • Type 1: Undisplaced fracture
  • Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex
  • Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex.

Clinical Presentation
  • Severe elbow pain, swelling, deformity, and loss of function may occur, and neurological symptoms like weakness in wrist flexion or the "hand of benediction" sign may also occur if the median nerve is affected.
  • Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity)
  • The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign)

X-ray Findings
  • Three bony parts relationship is maintained.
  • Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads.
  • Disturbed tear drop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion.

 

 

  • Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail.
  • Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment.

Management

Based on the type of fracture

  • Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion.
  • Displaced fractures
    • Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture)
    • Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture)
  • In Late presentation with swelling
    • Dunlop traction (skin)
    • Smith traction (skeletal)

Complications
  • Early complications
    • Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery)
    • Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve)
  • Delayed complications
    • Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion) (Option C)
    • Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome.
    • Elbow stiffness
    • Myositis ossificans.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Newborn

Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram(NSSK)
  • A training program launched by the Indian Government to equip doctors and nurses with essential newborn care skills, specifically addressing birth asphyxia.
  • The ultimate goal is to reduce newborn mortality and morbidity.

Goals/Objectives
  • Reduce Neonatal Mortality Rate: Decrease India's Neonatal Mortality Rate to single digits by 2030.
  • Improve Newborn Care Quality: Enhance the quality of newborn care.
  • Prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related Issues: Reduce morbidity and mortality linked to perinatal asphyxia.

Strategies

  • Capacity Building: Equip healthcare providers with necessary knowledge and skills.
  • Essential Newborn Care and Resuscitation Training.
  • Updated Curriculum and Training Methodology
  • Standardized Equipment and Supplies: Provide clean, functional equipment.
  • Effective Knowledge and Skill Transfer: Improve practical application of training.
  • Focus on "Golden Minute": Quick assessment and resuscitation. Promoting Clean Birth Practices: Adhere to WHO's "six cleans". Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC). Promotion: Encourage KMC for low birth weight babies.
  • Timely Immunization: Ensure vaccination before discharge.
  • Educate parents on newborn care.
  • Effective Neonatal Transport: Establish protocols for the safe transport of sick newborns.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the left knee region. He reports that the pain is often worse at night and mentions that he has been taking Aspirin to relieve the pain. An X-ray of the knee is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Osteoid Osteoma

A small, benign bone tumor composed of osteoid and woven bone with a surrounding halo of reactive bone

Demographics

Sex: Males > Females

Age: Young patients, but rare under 5 years and over 30.

Location

The diaphysis of long bones, especially the proximal tibia, and femur.

It can also occur in the spine, particularly the posterior arches.

Pathophysiology

The nidus releases prostaglandins which cause the characteristic pain that relieves on taking NSAIDs

Symptoms

Characterized by pain, often worse at night (Night crises), and relieved by NSAIDs (Therapeutic test).

When near joints, it may cause stiffness and effusion.

In the spine, it can lead to muscle spasms and scoliosis.

Radiology

X-Ray:

Dense sclerosis with a small, rounded area of osteolysis, often obscured by the surrounding sclerosis.

The characteristic lesion is less than 1.5 cm in diameter with a sclerotic margin and radiolucent nidus.

 

Isotope bone scans (Best investigation) are positive

Histology

Consists of a mesh of woven bone, osteoblastic rimming, osteoclasts, and dilated capillaries.

The mature osteoid forms the nidus, surrounded by dense, reactive bone and soft tissue with inflammatory changes.

Treatment

CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.

Surgical excision of the nidus (gold standard)

questions.text: A patient with pneumonia provides a BAL sample, as shown below. What is the likely pathogen responsible, and what is the relative management?
questions.explanation:
Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

Transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia causing bilateral infiltrates

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

 

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of diphtheria toxin?

options.label: A
options.text: ADP phosphorylation of EF-2 - Decreasing protein synthesis

questions.correct_answer: A. ADP phosphorylation of EF-2 - Decreasing protein synthesis
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Production and Structure
  • DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Consists of two fragments(Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons.

Role of Lysogenic β-phage
  • The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β-phage.
  • Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia.

Mechanism of Action
  • Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm.
  • Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis.

Potency
  • The lethal dose for a 250g guinea pig: is 0.0001 mg.
  • The estimated lethal dose for humans: 130 ng/kg body weight.

Systemic Effects
  • DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Myocarditis is potentially fatal.

Factors Affecting Production
  • Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium.
  • High production with low iron availability (0.1 mg/l); iron addition inhibits production (0.5 mg/l).

Toxoid Formation
  • Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid.
  • Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines.

Immunity
  • Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT.

Toxin

Source

Mechanism of Action

Diphtheria Toxin (DT)

Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Secreted by bacteria infected with tox-carrying β-phage.
  • Cleaved into fragments B and A.
  • Fragment B binds to human cell receptors.
  • Fragment A ADP-ribosylates elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis.

Exotoxin A

Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Secreted by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Inhibits protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells.
  • The mechanism involves a similar process to DT, disrupting EF-2 function.

questions.text: Infection in humans occurs by ingestion of quadrinucleate cysts through contaminated food or water. Which of the following is likely the cause of this infection?
Which of the following is the diagnostic test for monkeypox?
questions.explanation:
Monkeypox infections
  • The monkeypox virus belongs to the Orthopoxvirus genus.
  • Monkeypox is a rare zoonotic infection first recognized in captive monkeys in 1958.

Transmission
  • Infection likely occurs through direct contact with wild animals.
  • The exact primary reservoir host remains unidentified, but species such as squirrels, rabbits, and rodents can be infected.

Clinical features
  • Symptoms resemble those of smallpox but are generally milder.
  • Fever and rash.
  • Lymphadenopathy is a prominent feature in most cases, unlike in smallpox or chickenpox.

Complications
  • Respiratory distress
  • Secondary bacterial infections

Vaccination

The vaccinia vaccine can offer protection against monkeypox or lessen its severity.

Human-to-Human transmission
  • Transmission between humans is considered limited.
  • Estimates suggest that only about 15% of close contacts of infected individuals become infected.

Diagnosis
  • The CDC recommends the collection of two specimens, each from multiple lesions from different locations.
  • Confirmed via isolation in viral culture or by PCR for mpox virus DNA from a patient specimen.

questions.text: The image illustrates which vitamin deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Niacin (Vitamin B3)
Chemical Structure
  • Niacin: Pyridine-3-carboxylic acid.
  • Niacinamide: Acid amide derivative.
  • Active tissue form: Niacinamide
Coenzyme Forms and Functions
  • NAD+: Generates 2.5 ATPs in oxidative phosphorylation.
  • NADPH: Used in reductive biosynthesis (e.g., fatty acid synthesis).
  • Provides ADP-ribose for protein modification (ADP-ribosylation).
Synthesis and Metabolism
  • 60 mg of tryptophan = 1 mg niacin (requires pyridoxal phosphate-dependent kynureninase).
  • Niacin attaches to ribose phosphate, forming a mononucleotide, then combines with AMP to form dinucleotides.
Deficiency Causes
  • Dietary Deficiency: Staple diets like maize (bound niacin) or sorghum (leucine inhibits niacin conversion).
  • Enzyme Defects: Pyridoxal deficiency inhibits kynureninase activity.
  • Drugs: Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation.
  • Congenital Disorders: Hartnup disease (impaired tryptophan absorption and increased urinary excretion).
  • Carcinoid Syndrome: Excess tryptophan used for serotonin synthesis.
Clinical Condition
  • Pellagra: Niacin or tryptophan deficiency causing "rough skin".
  • Symptoms (3 Ds): Dermatitis (Casal’s necklace), Diarrhea (may involve blood/mucus), Dementia (irritability, poor memory, delirium).
Sources
  • Richest: Dried yeast, rice polishing, liver, peanuts, cereals, legumes, meat, fish.
  • 50% requirement met by tryptophan conversion.
RDA
  • Adults: 20 mg/day; Additional 5 mg during lactation.
Therapeutic Uses
  • Lowers serum cholesterol and Lp(a) by reducing free fatty acid flux from adipose tissue.
Toxicity
  • Excess (>50 mg/day): Vasodilation, itching, liver damage.

A chronic alcoholic patient presents with agitation, confusion, and gait abnormalities. What vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Features of Chronic Alcoholism

Vit. B12 Deficiency

(Option C)
  • Chronic alcohol use can lead to functional vitamin B12 deficiency, even if blood tests show normal levels.
  • Alcohol interferes with vitamin B12 absorption and metabolism.
  • Vitamin B12 is essential for DNA synthesis and maintaining healthy nerves and red blood cells.
  • Symptoms of B12 deficiency include fatigue, weakness, numbness, and balance problems.
  • Alcohol can damage the liver, which might cause falsely high B12 levels in blood tests, making diagnosis challenging.

Folate Deficiency

(Option B ruled out)
  • Folate (vitamin B9) deficiency is common in chronic alcoholics, affecting 6-80% of them.
  • Alcohol disrupts folate by impairing its absorption, transport, and liver storage.
  • Poor diet in alcoholics worsens folate deficiency.
  • Folate is crucial for making red blood cells and DNA.
  • Deficiency can cause megaloblastic anaemia and neurological issues like peripheral neuropathy and cognitive problems.

Hypoglycemia

 
  • Chronic alcohol consumption can cause low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), especially if not eating enough.
  • Alcohol produces a high NADH/NAD+ ratio in the cytoplasm, the high NADH level favours the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis.
  • Deficiency of pyruvate leads to inadequate formationof oxaloacetate which blocks gluconeogenesis
  • This results in low blood sugar levels.
  • Symptoms of alcohol-induced hypoglycemia include confusion, irritability, and, in severe cases, loss of consciousness.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used in a tube for collecting blood samples specifically for measuring alcohol concentration?
questions.explanation:
Blood Collection Tubes

Tube Type

Additives & Mechanism

Key Applications

Coagulation Tube

Sodium citrate binds calcium (Factor IV) to prevent clotting; anticoagulation reversed by adding calcium.
  • Used for coagulation studies.
  • Must be filled completely.

 

Serum Tube
  • Glass/silica activates clotting (Factor XII).
  • Some include gel separators to prevent cellular contamination.
  • Used for clinical chemistry, immunology, and serology.

 

Heparin Tube

Sodium/lithium heparin inhibits thrombin and Factor Xa to prevent clotting.
  • Common in biochemical tests.

 

EDTA Tube

EDTA chelates calcium irreversibly, preventing clotting.
  • Preferred for hematology.
  • Stable for enzymatic studies.

Glycolytic Inhibitor Tube

Sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis; may also include citrate, oxalate, or EDTA to prevent clotting.
  • Used to measure glucose and lactate levels.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient presents with pellagra-like skin eruptions during the spring season for the past 5 years. Laboratory tests reveal normal levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid (HIAA), high aminoaciduria, and normal urinary indole levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Pathogenesis

Mutation in SLC6A19 gene; Impaired transport of neutral amino acids across intestinal and kidney brush border epithelium

Clinical features
  • Photosensitivity
  • Pellagra-like rash (Decreased Niacin due to tryptophan deficiency)
  • Neurologic symptoms (ataxia, emotional instability) - Decreased serotonin due to tryptophan deficiency

Biochemical defect

Deficiency of nicotinamide synthesis

Diagnosis
  • Aminoaciduria (neutral amino acids) in urine and plasma
  • Demonstrate SLC6A19 defect

Treatment
  • Administration of nicotinamide/nicotinic acid
  • Protection from sunlight

Which structure does the anterior ethmoidal sinus drain into?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition
  • Air-filled cavities within the ethmoid bone
  • Part of the ethmoidal sinus system

Location
  • Between the nasal cavity and the orbit
  • Anterior group of ethmoidal air cells (compared to middle/posterior groups)

Drainage Pathway

Drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity via the infundibulum and hiatus semilunaris

Innervation

Supplied by the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (from CN V1 – ophthalmic division)

Blood Supply

Anterior ethmoidal artery (branch of ophthalmic artery)

Clinical Relevance

  • Close to orbit and anterior cranial fossa — risk of orbital cellulitis or intracranial spread if infected

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism presents with skin lesions. His diet primarily consists of polished rice. Based on his symptoms and dietary history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following poisonings?
questions.explanation:
Step

Details

Patient Positioning

Trendelenburg: Head down to prevent aspiration

Left lateral decubitus: Reduces chance of poison entering the duodenum

Tube Placement Confirmation

Inject air and listen for gastric bubbling sounds

Watch for coughing or bubbles (indicates misplacement in trachea)

Fluid Administration

Fluid is administered and aspirated using a syringe attached to the tube

Fluid Selection

Tap water for most cases

Normal saline for infants

Specific solutions (e.g., potassium permanganate) may be used for certain poisons

Residual Fluid

Leave a small amount of fluid to neutralize remaining poison

Complication

Details

Aspiration

Occurs in ~10% of cases. Risk of lung injury

Esophageal/Gastric Perforation

Can be life-threatening

Tube Misplacement

Misplaced into trachea, causing complications

Bleeding

Can occur with improper technique or pathology

Alternative

Description

Emetics

Induce vomiting in conscious patients

Dilution

Large water intake to dilute corrosive substances

Endoscopic/Surgical Removal

Used for toxic foreign bodies or drug packets

questions.text: Which drug can be used to treat both HIV and Hepatitis B?
questions.explanation:
Tenofovir (Nucleotide analogue RTI)

MOA
  • No phosphorylation is required (Option A)
  • Competitively inhibits viral reverse transcriptase
  • Incorporates into HIV DNA, causing chain termination (due to incomplete ribose ring)

Types
  • Tenofovir disoproxil: short-acting, more side effects
  • Tenofovir alafenamide: long-acting

Uses
  • DOC for HIV
  • DOC for Hepatitis B virus + HIV
  • HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (in combination with emtricitabine)

Side effects
  • Nephrotoxic (Acute renal failure)
    • Regular creatinine and phosphorus monitoring.
    • Avoid with NSAIDs
  • Fanconi syndrome (causes damage to PCT of nephron)
    • Leads to phosphate loss
    • Hypophosphatemic rickets, osteoporosis
  • Hepatitis B exacerbation with abrupt discontinuation

Contraindication
  • Renal disease (High creatinine)
    • Replace tenofovir with Zidovudine or Abacavir
  • Child < 10 years
  • Weight < 30 kg

Id

questions.text: A patient was taking metronidazole for diarrhoea. He attended a party where he consumed alcohol. Following this, he developed red rashes, itching all over his body, and a headache. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
Which of the following conditions is associated with the curtain falling sign?
questions.explanation:
Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment
  • Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.
  • Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.
  • Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.
  • Dark veil/Curtain falling sign/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.
  • Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.
  • Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.
  • Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.
  • Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment
  • Gradual, progressive visual loss
  • Typically painless
  • No associated flashes or floaters
  • Vitreoretinal bands present
  • No retinal breaks
  • Detached area - concave and localized
  • No shifting fluid

Exudative Retinal Detachment
  • Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss
  • No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.
  • Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances
  • Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.
  • Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

  • Inflammation of inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers. It spares sclera.
  • Acute bacterial endophthalmitis happens 1-7 days post intraocular surgery.

M/C causative organism
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis (Option B)

Presentation

  • Severe ocular pain
  • Redness
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Loss of vision
  • Red and swollen lids
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Circumcorneal congestion
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Ring infiltration
  • Yellow necrotic wound edges
  • Hypopyon
  • Oedematous and muddy iris
  • Yellow pupil reflex due to purulent exudation
  • Vitreous exudation which causes amaurotic cat's-eye reflex
  • Raised intraocular pressure initially

Treatment

  • Intravitreal antibiotics:
    • First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Ceftazidime 2.25 mg
    • Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Amikacin 0.4 mg
  • Topical antibiotics
  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Steroid Therapy
  • Supportive Therapy
  • Vitrectomy - if no improvement in 48-72 hours or if severe infection with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face
  • If blind - no perception of light - Evisceration.

questions.text: A patient has sudden loss of vision and there is no fundus glow. There is no history of trauma, what could be the likely cause?
What diagnosis is suggested by having different refractive powers (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye)?
questions.explanation:
Type

Cause

Key Features

Strabismic Amblyopia

The brain suppresses input from one eye due to constant squint (strabismus).

Common cause; underdevelopment of vision in the deviated eye.

Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia

Hindered vision due to obstruction from early life (e.g., congenital cataracts, ptosis, dense central corneal opacity).

Lack of visual stimulation affects normal development.

Anisometropic Amblyopia (Option C ruled out)

A significant difference in refractive error between eyes.

The brain favours the clearer eye, leading to amblyopia in the other.

Ametropic Amblyopia

High uncorrected refractive errors in both eyes.

Bilateral; is less severe compared to other types.

Meridional Amblyopia

Uncorrected astigmatism affecting specific visual meridians.

Affects one or both eyes depending on the astigmatism degree.

Premature causes:

Symptoms

  • Asthenopic symptoms (eye fatigue)
  • Intermittent diplopia

Treatment Options

Optical Treatment:

  • Convex glasses based on age
  • Correct refractive error for distance first

Pharmacological therapy:1.25% Pilocarpine(FDA-approved)

Surgical options:

  • LASIK (Monovision/presbyopic multifocal-LASIK)
  • Corneal inlays
  • Multifocal IOL placement following lens extraction

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for the patient with the given ABG analysis report: pH 7.17 Na= 139.7mEq.L pCO2 25.7mmHg K= 5.1mEq.L, pO2 97mm Hg Blood glucose 334mg/dL SatO2 99% HCO3 at 17.4mEq.L, BE of -8.6
questions.explanation:
Metabolic acidosis

Definition
  • Primary decrease in HCO3⁻ or increase in H⁺ ions
  • Characterized by ↓ pH and ↓ HCO3⁻
  • Compensatory mechanism: ↓ PaCO2 through hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing)

Types

High anion gap (AG > 12 mEq/L)

Normal anion gap (AG 6-12 mEq/L)

Causes

(Mnemonic: MUDPILES)

  • M: Methanol
  • U: Uremia (Renal failure)
  • D: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • P: Paraldehyde, Phenformin, Propylene glycol
  • I: Iron tablets, Isoniazid
  • L: Lactic acidosis
  • E: Ethylene glycol
  • S: Salicylates (late phase)

 

(Mnemonic: HARD UP)

  • H: Hyperalimentation (TPN)
  • A: Acetazolamide
  • R: Renal Tubular Acidosis
  • D: Diarrhea
  • U: Ureteral diversion
  • P: Pancreatic fistula
  • GIT fistulas

Clinical Features

General Features:

  • Lethargy
  • Confusion
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Deep, rapid breathing (Kussmaul)

 

Specific Features:

  • DKA: Fruity breath, polyuria, polydipsia
  • Uremia: Itching, volume overload
  • Lactic acidosis: Shock, hypotension
  • Toxic ingestion: Visual disturbances (methanol), oxalate crystals (ethylene glycol)

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician expressing her desire to become pregnant in the next few months. She is currently not taking any medications or supplements and wants to know what preventive measures she should take before conception. Which vitamin is given to prevent neural tube defects?

A 28-year-old G1P0 woman has been pushing for 2 hours with minimal progression. The obstetrician is considering outlet forceps assistance. On examination, the fetal head is visible at the vaginal opening. Outlet forceps are applied at which station?
questions.explanation:
Procedure

Criteria

Outlet forceps
  • Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
  • Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
  • Fetal head is at or on perineum
  • Head is OA or OP or
  • Head is right or left OA or OP position but rotation ≤45 degrees

Low forceps (2 types)
  • Fetal station is ≥+2 cm but not on the pelvic floor, and:
  • (a) Rotation ≤45 degrees is required or
  • (b) Rotation >45 degrees is required

Midforceps
  • Fetal station is between 0 and +2 cm

Prerequisites
  • Engaged head
  • Vertex presentation
  • Known fetal head position
  • CPD not suspected
  • Fetal weight estimated
  • Experienced operator
  • Ruptured membranes
  • Completely dilated cervix
  • Adequate anesthesia
  • Emptied maternal bladder
  • No fetal coagulopathy
  • No fetal demineralization disorder
  • Informed consent completed
  • Willingness to abandon OVD

CPD = cephalopelvic disproportion; OA = occiput anterior; OP = occiput posterior; OVD = operative vaginal delivery.

questions.explanation:
Inclusion Bodies Seen In Multiple Myeloma

Russel bodies:
  • Location: Intracytoplasmic
  • Composition:
    • Eosinophilic
    • Round
    • Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae filled with condensed immunoglobulin.

.

Dutcher bodies
  • Location: Intranuclear.
  • Composition: Globular inclusions containing accumulated immunoglobulin.

Plasma Cell Variants In Multiple Myeloma

Mott cells

  • Contain Grape-like cytoplasmic droplets.
  • Composition: Inclusion bodies, fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.

Flame cells
  • Appearance: Fiery red cytoplasm.
  • Cause: High concentration of immunoglobulin as bright red granules within the cytoplasm.
  • Often seen in IgA subtype myeloma.

 

 

Rouleaux formation
  • High levels of M protein in the blood cause red cells to stick to one another in linear arrays in smears, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation. (Option B ruled out)
  • It is also seen in s lupus erythematosus and early HIV infection.

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple myeloma:
  • ≥10% clonal bone marrow plasma cells (or) a biopsy-proven bony or extra medullary plasmacytoma

                           + (PLUS)

  • Evidence of one or more multiple myeloma defining events (MDE): (CRAB features)
    • HyperCalcemia (S.Ca2+ >11g/dl)
    • Renal failure (S. Creatinine >2mg/dl)
    • Anaemia (Hb <10gm)
    • Lytic Bone lesions are attributable to the plasma cell disorder.

                                 (OR)

  • One or more biomarkers of malignancy (SLIM criteria)
    • Bone marrow clonal plasmacytosis ≥60% (Sixty per cent)
    • Serum involved/uninvolved free Light chain (FLC) ratio ≥ 100 (provided involved FLC is ≥100 mg/L)
    • >1 focal lesion on MRI.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of fatigue, pallor, and weakness. Laboratory tests reveal a low hemoglobin (Hb) level, but the reticulocyte count is normal. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pure Red Cell Aplasia

Definition

A condition characterized by anemia, reticulocytopenia, and absent or rare erythroid precursor cells in bone marrow with normal white cell and platelet production

Classification

Congenital:

  • Diamond-Blackfan anemia
  • Diagnosed at birth or early childhood

Acquired:

  • Thymoma
  • MDS (5s- syndrome)
  • Cancer
  • Autoimmune conditions
  • Viral infections (especially B19 parvovirus)

Clinical Associations
  • Thymoma (most frequent)
  • Lymphoid malignancies
  • Autoimmune disorders
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Pregnancy

Pathophysiology
  • T-cell mediated immune response
  • Antibodies to erythropoietin
  • Neutralizing antibodies to B19 parvovirus
  • Direct chemical toxicity or immune destruction

Treatment

General Approach:

  • Identify and treat underlying cause
  • Regular monitoring of hemoglobin levels
  • Supportive care with transfusions

Specific Treatments:

  • Immunosuppression (corticosteroids, cyclosporine, ATG, azathioprine)
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin for B19 parvovirus infection
  • Thymectomy if thymoma present
  • Iron chelation as needed

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with ptosis, diplopia, and generalized muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. She has difficulty chewing and swallowing, especially in the evening. A Tensilon test is positive. Which investigation is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Evaluation: Recognizing the Signs

  • History:
    • Focus on the onset, progression, diurnal variation and fluctuating muscle weakness.
  • Physical Examination:
    • Assess muscle strength.
    • Identify characteristic signs:
      • Ptosis
      • Diplopia
      • Cogan's lid twitch sign
    • Rule out other neurological conditions.

Diagnostic Tests: Confirming the Suspicion

Test

Description

Tensilon Test
  • Administers edrophonium bromide intravenously.
  • May show transient muscle function improvement; not highly reliable.

Repetitive Nerve Stimulation (RNS)
  • Specialized nerve conduction study.
  • Reveals a decremental response in muscle strength with repeated stimulation, indicating impaired neuromuscular transmission.

Single Fiber Electromyography (SFEMG)
  • SFEMG techniques allow assessment of two important features of the motor unit: jitter and fiber density (FD).
  • SFEMG is the most sensitive clinical test for neuromuscular junction disease and is often abnormal in clinically unaffected muscles in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG) and Lambert-Eaton myasthenia (LEM).

Antibody Testing
  • Detects auto-antibodies related to MG.
  • Acetylcholine Receptor (AChR) Antibodies: Most common, block AChR function.
  • Muscle-Specific Kinase (MuSK) Antibodies: Disrupt AChR clustering and stabilization.

Thoracic CT Scan

Essential to rule out thymoma, especially in patients with negative AChR antibody tests.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of tuberculosis now complains of abdominal distension and pedal edema. On examination, his neck veins are prominent. His chest x-ray is given below. Which of the following findings will be likely seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus Paradoxus: Hallmark finding. A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: Which of the following intestinal pathologies is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis?
questions.explanation:
Celiac Disease

Definition

Autoimmune disorder triggered by ingesting gluten-containing foods in genetically susceptible individuals.

It is influenced by HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8.

Pathogenesis

Clinical features

Adults:

  • Commonly between the ages of 30 and 60.
  • More frequent in females
  • Silent celiac disease (positive serology and villous atrophy without symptoms)
  • Latent celiac disease (positive serology is not accompanied by villous atrophy)
  • It may be associated with chronic diarrhoea, bloating, chronic fatigue, or asymptomatic.
  • Anaemia (iron and vitamin malabsorption).
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis (itchy, blistering skin lesion) might be present. (Option C)

 

Pediatric cases:

  • Both sexes were affected equally.
  • It may present with malabsorption.
  • Begins after the introduction of gluten to the diet (6-24 months of age)
  • Manifestations include irritability, abdominal distention, anorexia, chronic diarrhoea, failure to thrive, weight loss, or muscle wasting.
  • It may also present as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, or constipation.
  • Extraintestinal complaints include arthritis or joint pain, aphthous stomatitis, iron deficiency anaemia, delayed puberty, and short stature.

Serum markers
  • IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase (tTG): Most sensitive.
  • Anti-endomysial antibodies (EMA): Most specific.
  • IgG antibodies against gliadin (a component of gluten).

Histology

Biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum:

  • Increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis).
  • Crypt hyperplasia (Increased mitosis).
  • Villous atrophy (Reduced mucosal surface area, causing malabsorption).
  • Inflammatory cell infiltration.

questions.text: Which among the following is associated with Cryoglobulinemia?
A patient following a road traffic accident (RTA) with a crush injury presents with crepitus and a reddish-brown wound within 3 days after amputation. What is the most likely condition?
questions.explanation:
Gas Gangrene

A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries.

Cause

Clostridium perfringens

Incubation period

<24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks

Sources and predisposing factors
  • Contaminated soil and feces.
  • Wounds with necrotic or foreign material.
  • Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations.
  • Anaerobic environments in the wound.

Common sites of infection
  • Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks.
  • Subscapular region in the upper limb.

Clinical features
  • Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity.
  • Serosanguineous discharge.
  • Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae.
  • Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus.

Complication

  • Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure.
  • Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections.
  • Death occurs in critically ill patients.

Investigation

  • X-ray: Gas in soft tissues.
  • Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils.
  • Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis.
  • CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds.

Treatment

  • High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously.
  • Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously.
  • All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds.
  • Amputation done in severe cases
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Prevention

  • Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds.
  • Devitalized wounds should not be sutured.
  • Adequate cleaning of wounds with H₂O₂ and normal saline.
  • Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic.

Image

Osteoporosis circumscripta: A circumscribed patch of osteoporosis in the skull.

Tam O'Shanter sign: The skull's expansion and flattened base create the appearance of the skull tilting over the facial structures (due to the thickening of the frontal bone).

 

Blade of grass appearance or candle flame sign: Flame-shaped lesion extending along the shaft of the bone.

Picture frame vertebra:

The vertebrae appear enlarged and have a thickened cortical bone due to excessive bone remodeling and disorganized osteoblastic activity.

 

Ivory vertebra:

The homogeneous, radiopaque appearance results from increased bone density caused by abnormal osteoblastic activity, leading to excessive bone formation.

 

Lincoln sign or Black Beard sign: Increased radiotracer uptake in the mandible gives it a distinctive black beard appearance that signifies abnormal bone metabolism in Paget’s disease.

Banana fractures: Occur in a region of abnormal bone.

questions.text: During the procedure shown below which one of the following substances is uptaken by the cancer cells?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism

Description

Aerobic Glycolysis

Cancer cells rely heavily on glycolysis, increasing glucose and 18F-FDG uptake, even with oxygen.

Transport & Trapping

GLUT-1 transporters mediate glucose entry. 18F-FDG is phosphorylated and trapped inside cells.

Tumor Heterogeneity

Differences in tumor subtype, size, and microvasculature affect 18F-FDG uptake.

Implication

Details

Prognostic Indicator

Higher 18F-FDG uptake correlates with worse prognosis (e.g., shorter DFS in invasive ductal carcinoma).

Reverse Warburg Effect

Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) increase glycolysis in tumor cells via metabolic coupling.

Treatment Monitoring

PET imaging tracks changes in 18F-FDG uptake, reflecting therapy responses targeting glycolysis or mitochondria.

questions.correct_answer: A. Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Immediate Transfusion Reactions

Delayed Transfusion Reactions

Onset Time

Within hours of transfusion

Days to weeks after transfusion

Cause

Immunologic reactions, hemolytic or non-hemolytic

Immune-mediated, often involving minor antigen sensitization

Presentation

Fever, chills, Dyspnea (TRALI, TACO), Acute respiratory distress (TRALI), Pulmonary oedema (TACO), hypothermia, electrolyte abnormalities, coagulopathy, acid-base disorders and hyperkalemia

Fever, jaundice, Gradual decline in haemoglobin levels (hemolysis)

Severity

Can range from mild to life-threatening

Generally less severe than immediate reactions

Examples
  • Febrile non-hemolytic reaction (FNHTR)
  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)
  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)

Delayed hemolytic reaction

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with pain, redness, and swelling around his great toe. His serum uric acid level is 9.4 mg/dL. His mother also mentions that he frequently bites his lips and has symptoms of spasticity and dystonia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Lesch-Nyhan syndrome

Cause

Deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT)

Inheritance

X-linked recessive

Variants
  • Classic Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Undetectable HPRT levels.
  • Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome: Partial HPRT deficiency with variable neurological dysfunction.

Clinical Features
  • Self-injurious behaviour: Biting lips, fingers, tongue; begins with tooth eruption.
  • Cognitive impairment: Intellectual disability ranging from mild to severe.
  • Movement disorder: Starts with hypotonia, progresses to dystonia, choreoathetosis, oromandibular dystonia, and inspiratory stridor.
  • Oculomotor apraxia: Difficulty controlling eye movements.
  • Dysarthric speech: Difficulty speaking clearly.

Complications
  • Hyperuricemia: Causes gout and kidney stones.
  • Neurological symptoms: Abnormalities in the dopamine system, reduced dopamine transporters.

Treatment
  • Allopurinol: Reduces uric acid levels and manages hyperuricemia.
  • Symptom management: Controls movement disorders and self-injurious behaviours.

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient has presented to you with features of a nerve injury involving right upper limb. On examination, the patient is able to carry out flexion at metacarpo-phalangeal joint and extension at interphalangeal joint. The most likely nerve involved is?
A 40-year-old female patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain; further investigations show elevated PTH levels and renal calculi. Which of the following investigations should be done next?
questions.explanation:
Hyperparathyroidism

Functions of the parathyroid gland
  • Increase the level of calcium in the body (Subperiosteal bone resorption).
  • Decrease the level of phosphorus in the body (Urinary excretion of phosphorus).

Types

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid adenoma and parathyroid hyperplasia)
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism

Radiological features

  • Subperiosteal resorption usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side, leading to a concavity of bone (the earliest bone change).
  • The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull).
  • Brown tumor or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions resulting from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can cause bone expansion, often accompanied by hemorrhage and granulation tissue (more common in primary hyperparathyroidism).

 

  • Rugger jersey spine: Characterized by alternating black and white striations, with sclerosed white end plates and black vertebral bodies; commonly seen in renal osteodystrophy (secondary hyperparathyroidism).

questions.text: Which structure is located approximately 25 cm from the central incisor?
A 3-year-old child immediately cries after breastfeeding, followed by vomiting and diarrhea. Which enzyme deficiency might be responsible?
questions.explanation:
Galactosemia

Enzyme Deficiency
  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase (GALT) - Classical type
  • Galactokinase - benign disease with only oil drop cataract.
  • Epimerase - SNHL + symptoms of classical type

(Low galactose-based diet can be given, which is contraindicated in the classical type)

Pathophysiology
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate (toxic causing jaundice, and liver damage)
  • Inability to metabolize galactose from milk
  • Damage to liver, kidney, and brain

Clinical Features
  • Hepatic: Jaundice, hepatomegaly
  • GI: Vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive
  • CNS: Seizures, intellectual disability
  • Eyes: Oil drop cataracts
  • Increased risk of E. coli sepsis

Diagnosis
  • Reducing substance in urine (positive) (Positive Benedict test but negative glucose oxidase test)
  • Direct enzyme (GALT) assay
  • Genetic testing (Perinatal diagnosis is possible)

Management
  • Lactose-free diet
  • Breast Milk contraindicated
  • Soy-based or elemental formulas
  • Calcium supplementation

questions.text: A 20-year-old female who is a known case of sickle cell anaemia was rushed to the emergency department with a complaint of extreme pain in the legs and fingers for the past 4 hours. Further examination revealed pain and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, and investigations showed sickle cells on peripheral blood smear and high bilirubin(indirect). What is the diagnosis?
A patient who has been treated for TB in the past now presented with hemoptysis. Make a diagnosis based on the given X-ray.
questions.explanation:
Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA)

 

  • ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction affecting the major upper lobe airways leading to upper lobe bronchiectasis.
  • It is associated with Elevated serum IgE levels, Positive serum precipitins for Aspergillus, Respiratory symptoms similar to asthma, Skin reactivity to Aspergillus

 

Radiographic Findings:

  • Non-segmental opacities primarily in the upper lobes
  • Lobar collapse
  • Branching thick tubular opacities due to mucus and fungus (known as the "finger-in-glove sign" or "Y" shape)
  • Occasional pulmonary cavitation

Aspergillus Mycetomas/ Aspergilloma/ Fungal Ball

 

  • Aspergillus mycetomas are saprophytic growths that inhabit preexisting lung cavities,
  • These are predominantly found in the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes.

 

CT Characteristics:

  • Appears as a mass with soft-tissue attenuation within a lung cavity.
  • The mass is usually separated from the cavity wall by an airspace, known as the "Air crescent" or Monod sign.
  • The position of the mass may change between prone and supine orientations, demonstrating its mobility.

Angioinvasive Aspergillosis

Fig: Halo sign

 

  • Primarily occurs in immunocompromised individuals,
  • Involves invasion and blockage of small to medium pulmonary arteries.
  • Leads to the formation of necrotic hemorrhagic nodules or infarcts.

 

CT Findings:

  • Commonly presented as multiple nodules surrounded by a halo of ground-glass attenuation "halo sign" or pleural-based wedge-shaped consolidations. (Option A)
  • The bronchial cut-off sign indicates central necrosis.
  • Nodular opacities tend to be widespread across several lung lobes, unlike the clustered peribronchial opacities seen in bacterial infections.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child was brought to the OPD with complaints of low-grade fever, headache and mild upper respiratory tract symptoms for the last 4 days. On examination, an erythematous rash was found on the cheeks. The parents said the rash developed on the cheeks first and then spread out to involve his trunk and limbs. The causative agent of this disease has a single-stranded DNA. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth disease)

Causative agent

Parvovirus B19

Age group affected

5 to 15 years (70% of cases)

Incubation period

4-28 days

Transmission

Respiratory droplets. Transmission rates among contacts are 15-30%.

Clinical features
  • Prodromal phase: Low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection symptoms.
  • The characteristic rash in this condition is a "slapped cheek appearance”, presenting as erythematous flushing on the face.
  • The erythematous rash spreads to the trunk and proximal extremities as a lacy or reticulated pattern.

 

Management

Self-limiting disease

questions.text: A young patient in the first decade of life presents with grade II splenic injury with no active bleeding. What is the management?
questions.explanation:
American Association for the Surgery of Trauma - AAST Spleen Injury scale

Grade I (Minor Injury):
  • Subcapsular hematoma affects less than 10% of the splenic surface area.
  • Capsular tear that is less than 1 cm in depth without active bleeding.

Grade II:

 
  • Subcapsular hematoma involving 10-50% of the splenic surface area.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma less than 5 cm in diameter.
  • Laceration between 1 and 3 cm in depth that doesn't involve trabecular vessels.

Grade III:

 
  • Subcapsular hematoma covering more than 50% of the splenic surface area or expanding hematoma.
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma greater than 5 cm or expanding.
  • Laceration is more than 3 cm in depth or involves trabecular vessels.

Grade IV:

 
  • Laceration affects segmental or hilar vessels, with evidence of devascularisation involving more than 25% of the spleen.
  • Injury to the splenic parenchyma that results in major blood loss.
  • Any injury in the presence of splenic vascular injury or active bleeding within the splenic capsule

Grade V (Severe Injury):
  • Completely shattered spleen.
  • Vascular injury involving the splenic hilum that results in complete devascularization of the spleen.

questions.text: A barium swallow radiographic image of a woman with dysphagia is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Achalasia cardia

Definition

It is characterised by the progressive degeneration of ganglion cells in the esophageal wall. This leads to a loss of peristalsis in the lower esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax during swallowing

Clinical Features

 
  • Dysphagia: May initially affect liquids more than solids.
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Chest Pain
  • Weight Loss

Investigations:

Esophageal Manometry

Gold Standard: This is the definitive diagnostic test for achalasia. It measures the pressure and pattern of muscle contractions in the esophagus. (Option A)

  • Elevated resting LES pressure (typically > 45 mmHg).
  • Incomplete LES relaxation.
  • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • Periodic contractions with normal amplitude or high amplitude contractions (type I and II achalasia).

Barium Swallow (Esophagram)

Dilated esophagus with a narrowing at the LES (Bird beak appearance).

Endoscopy:

Normal mucosa but may show dilated esophagus with possible food debris, It is important to rule out other causes of dysphagia, such as tumors.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the outpatient department 10 days postpartum with complaints of a fluctuant breast mass with tenderness, high-grade fever, and cracked nipples. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms

Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided preferred over surgical incision.
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.
